Posted: July 13, 2011
												For those of you who've played M&B Warband, what you'll find is a somewhat more limited but much more story-driven game, set during a very dynamic era in Eastern Europe's history. It's somewhat more limited as there are fewer 'roleplay' options and the economy seems less well developed, It's much more story-driven because instead of the over-arching "take over the world" objective, you have three different stories (Cossack, Muscovite, and Polish) you can engage in and leave 'on the back burner' at any time to return to the free-roaming sandbox world, which still exists largely unchanged from Warband. AI improvements: By default, a pike and shot formation will shelter the shot under the pikes. Ideal for defeating cavalry. Musketeers can kneel and fire. Reloading can be achieved on the move, though at a walk. In terms of the engine, WFAS and Warband are essentially identical, so expect smooth performance on any remotely reasonable gaming computer even at maximum settings.

Posted: May 8, 2016
												I played through the original Mount and Blade before I got to With Fire and Sword. Mount & Blade: With Fire & Sword is a definite upgrade in the Mount and Blade series. The ability to use firearms makes it a lot more interesting. However the missions are similar to the regular Mount and Blade, which was so fun to play and quite large. So if you already have played through the regular Mount and Blade and loved it you will like the additions in With Fire and Sword. It takes time getting used to the world, and it is a large world. You will need to fend for your soldiers and build your army slowly in order to have a chance to really dominate. This game requires a lot of patience but it is fun to storm the castles with your army. Once you have a few castles under your control it becomes a lot more easier to manage the game. the trading system is a nice thing as well if you have the patience for it. Learning which resources are needed in different places can take some time. Overall great game.

Posted: April 19, 2016
												This game is like a more tactical version of Chivalry. The levels and teams are very historically accurate, from the way they look and sound, right down to how the weapons handle. This is not a very fast-paced FPS shooter, it's more of an antique combat simulator. Mount and Blade really belongs in its own special category of tactical FPS. When a server gets going with a good team on both sides, it can be a lot of fun. I also enjoy skirmish mode. I have never found much time for the campaigns. Buy it on sale, and it's some of the most unique fun you can have for the money.

Posted: August 31, 2015
												Could have been great, but sadly isn't.Pro's:Weapons feel lovely. Both melee and ranged.Uniforms are pretty. Not sure if they are historically accurate but they look good enough to a layman such as myself.Quest system for leaders and villages is very much improved over vanilla. Not great but still, its an improvement.Cons:The AI is what breaks it. The game could be fun if you ignore the other bugs but sadly this is the real issue. The issue is In city fights/seiges the AI will just stand there not attacking and changing weapons back and fouth. You can literally walk into a bunch of 50+ of them and punch them all to death slowly without any sort of resistance. Its  totally game breaking.The map is very boring (kind of reminds me of seven kingdoms if anyone remembers that from the 90s) as its basically all plain with no features and the tile set is a very noticable single small repeating square of colour and the occasional mountain line or river.Theres alot of minor details that I could go on with such as certain factions items are a bit imbalanced such as janissary armour being paper thin etc but those are minor. Theres nothing 'really new' over M&B other than a usually bugged out and uncompletable quest line. Consider this a mod for M&B with a price tag. Sadly you are better off with one of the M&B free mods which are very close to this. Theres quite a few available and they are all superior.Verdict: 4/10. Could have been great, but its lazily finished with lots of game breaking bugs.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												This game seems to be a lot less fun in the early game than Mount & Blade: Warband because it's harder to get started. For instance, you can't simply recruit men from villages and level them up anymore. Also, firearms aren't really that fun to play with, given their inaccuracy and very long reload times. They're interesting, but not fun, at least as far as I could see.I wanted to play more to see if it got better later on, but the performance of this game is terrible. I can run Mount & Blade: Warband with maximum settings and hundreds of men on the field at 200 FPS, but this game on low settings and 20 men on the field gets only 20-50 FPS. (It seems to be more related to terrain than battle size.) It might be okay if the frame rate was at least constant, but it stutters quite a bit, causing the gameplay to speed up and slow down frequently, which messes up the timing in combat. There are numerous forum posts from other people with the same problem, but no good solutions, so I found this game to be essentially unplayable.

Posted: August 28, 2015
												Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword takes place in 17th century Eastern Europe. There are five factions to choose from, the Polish Commonwealth, Muscovite Tsardom, Cossack Hetmanate, Kingdom of Sweden, and Crimean Khanate. Each faction has unique troops each with its pros and cons. There is a leveling system in this game so you can upgrade your character throughout the game. You can play in first person or third person. Throughout the game, you will recruit soldiers to join your troop. They can be upgraded once they have a certain amount of experience. You can also hire mercenaries too. In combat, you can command your troops to form a certain formation. The game is very similar to Mount & Blade: Warband. There is some addition in Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword, there are new weapons such as muskets, pistols, and grenades. There are some UI improvements as well.Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword is quite similar to its predecessor, Warband. The buildings and troop uniform look accurate. The towns and villages look nice. I really like the UI improvements, it's really neat. There are many mods for this game as well.However, there are some bugs and glitches in the campaign. The animation when someone died because of getting shot looks weird. There isn't much ragdoll from the grenades as well. Some aspects of the game, such as the loading screen, aren't optimized for widescreen resolution. There is no Steam Cloud support for this game too.To conclude, despite some of its flaws, Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword is still a very fun and addicting game. I really enjoy the hours I played it.

Posted: December 28, 2015
												Gun powder weapons spice up the action but the muskets are WAY too over powered. This game takes place around the 16th century when guns weren't very reliable and insanely inaccurate, but in With Fire & Sword, you can snipe someone from about 200 feet away and get a freaking headshot on them about 80% of the time. This goes for singleplayer and multiplayer. Mounted units can still destroy any unit, which is fine. It's fun running over people while on horseback. You can recruit armies quickly with several types of mercenaries, it is easier to manage towns, earn money, and there are more options to manage your armies now in battle. It's pretty cool getting a few dozen musket units all lined up in a row and fire at the same time. Grenades do exactly what you would think. Blasting a hole into the side wall of a castle and charging in is certainly alot faster and easier then using ladders during sieges. There's plenty of mods you can find to set your fix, just like the other Mount & Blade games. There are some other improvements here and there over Warband, but I think Warband is still the must have game out of this series and stand alone expansions. With Fire & Sword is still worth getting in my eyes; you'll just have to get used to the additions of guns and other new modes and features.

Posted: August 17, 2015
												Mount and Blade: With Fire and Sword is an interesting.. Sequel/Standalone whatever it is to Mount and Blade and Mount and Blade: Warband.While it proudly boasts the classic Mount and Blade style game play, allowing you free roam to do whatever you please in the world, be it conquer it, hunt bandits, or even just run caravans, there are a few things that make it exceptionally notable from the original game and it's sequel.The first, and most likely the most noticably, is the guns. Unlike the original and Warband, which were set in a medieval-esque setting, fit with Crossbows, Bows and Throwing weapons as the only ranged weapons, With Fire and sword is placed in the 17th century Polish-Lithuanian commonwealth, and, as such, the game features guns. Most people see this in the game, and are offput by it (Much like many were to Age of Empires III) figuring it to be game-ruining or cheap. Taleworlds are smarter than that though, and the method to which they added guns is quite interesting. Mount and blade is renowned for it's complex systems for calculating damage accuracy and speed, and the way they introduced guns fits perfectly into this. You see, the guns, like any weapon real life or (good) fantasy, have both pros and cons.Starting off with the pros, guns are incredibly powerful. A good shot to a person can very easily kill them instantly, and someone without a shield (something the game encourages by making them a bit pricey) can't block the shot. That on it's own would be ridiculously powerful, but it is weighed against the incredibly long reload times, limited shots and incredible inaccuracy. The weapons are treated by the game to be a sort of glass cannon: Incredibly powerful, but on it's own? Useless. Anyone with a mind wouldn't ride on their horse with a gun and without a sword. This makes for some incredibly interesting strategy and thought to be combined with the weapon, as is usual with the series.The second difference is in troop management. The player can only recruit so many troops from villages at the beginning, this means that they cannot stack up troops as they would in the other two games. Instead soldiers in the earlier game are comprised almost if not entirely of mercenaries. If this were how it were in Warband, the game would be absolutely unplayable. In With fire and sword, however, there are some major changes. Firstly, the mercenaries you build your armies out of can be hired as much as you like from a mercenary camp, and more interestingly, at a mercenary camp you can actually choose what gear your troops have (Much like with companions, although a bit less customizable)This allows you to tailor your army however you like it, albeit at a cost.  This feature is incredibly fun and interesting, although I believe it should have been optional to have the village recruitments for the most part turned off in the beginning, to allow more freedom.A downside to With Fire and Sword though is the lack of mods. This is of course not the fault of the developers, and much more the fanbase. The game didn't hit as much success as Warband did with the community, despite how well the game compares to it, and so the mod base, compared to Warband, is empty. This is a catastrophic shame, although even without mods the game on its own still has much merit.The game also isn't quite as memorable as the other games were. While the other games had their own original nations, With Fire and Sword draws more from actual history, and so contains real nations exclusively. This means that, while they are different culturally and strategically, they aren't as exuberant and different as the ones in the original games. The original two had everything from the desert dwelling Sarranids to the steppe venturing Khergits and snow wandering Vaegirs. While you could see the cultures they were drawn from, it was still interesting to see them all interacting with one another, and they were distinctly different. Not as many people know the difference between Russian troops and Polish ones as people do Viking and Arabian ones. These features aren't inherently bad, though. They can appeal greatly to a history buff with a passion for the 17th century. It is simply that these features aren't as appealing to a wide audience. Don't let me dissaude you though, With Fire and Sword is a wonderful game, even if you aren't as into history as some other people are. It holds up extremely well to it's counterparts and in some ways surpasses it. And, if you enjoyed either of the first two games, I highly reccomend you give this one a try, even if you don't like the game in the end, you won't regret any time spent in it.

												I've got mixed feelings about this one, and generally I don't vote no. In this case though, the game feels incredibly unpolished. I'll take on missions that appear to be identical (confronting village raiders at midnight) and sometimes arrive with my men and armed, sometimes arrive by myself and unarmed. Trial and error is really the way to proceed and that irritates the hell out of me.The battles feel gritty and historically grounded. If you have the patience for this sort of attention to detail at the expense of a smooth ride, the game is probably for you. I, on the other hand, have become incredibly impatient.UPDATED: Ingri is a badass. Apparently the only useful woman in the time period, who makes up for her fellow females (who give no quests, and can provide no information or services) by outshining every other NPC. Once I had her in the party and started getting into trading the game became much more managable. I still think the game could use a lot more polish, but if you're willing to get over the learning curve it's incredibly fun, especially at the price point.

Posted: April 29, 2015
												While this game may not have the charm of M&B:Warband, it definitely scratches that itch to command an army of musket wielding troops and watch them pepper an army of idiot peasants trying to run screaming away from you.The game itself is much like the rest of the series, start out with almost nothing but the weapons and a horse you are assigned by difficulty, then complete 'quests', join a faction and try to rule the world.  A cast of semi interesting characters join you on your ride through fake history as you lay waste to the country-side.The customizable troops you can get is a nice touch, and if you get enough cash (eventually you will via plunder or trade) you can effectively travel with an army of epic geared troops, slaughtering everything in your (or your lords) name.Story?  Bah who needs one in this style of game?  Your story is the story, basically making it so you yourself get to design your own story by destroying army after army.  Or die trying.  And stuff.Open world games are easy to get lost in, and while the graphics are dated (but being able to display 200+ troops in a FPS styled RTS is impressive in it's own right) there are worse things in life.I strongly recommend this game for people who wish that M&B had muskets instead of crossbows, as while the story isn't a big leap, the combat definitely feels fresh.  Skyrim this may not be, but in Skyrim you can't honestly lead 200+ troops around attacking people/villages at random or capture yourself a few castles without some serious modding.Also look into the mods/DLC for this game if you like multiplayer, the community is pretty cool.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												Mount & Blade the game is a wonderful creature. I've played many hours in this franchise, throughout several games, and I am nothing short of amazed. The basis for the game is so simple, I often wonder why more developers haven't tried something like this, but then I get knocked off a siege ladder for the second consecutive time by my screaming comrades, and feel like playing Call of Duty 36.This installment is a magnificent addition to the franchise - perhaps less-so on the RTS side of it, but definitely moreso on the combat/castle siege part of it. And that's one of the most beautiful parts to the game: There are many sides to it!Though slightly more limited than some of its predecessors (mods included), WF&S is an explosive entry into an explosive era in our world history: The era of the discovery and hugely widespread use of powder weapons.Being a generally combat-based game, this is the feature which I believe shines the most -- another facet of combat.Firearms bring an entirely new level of gameplay. Crossbows had a similar feel, but the sensation of riding down fleeing cossacks and driving a pistol ball into the small of their backs is hard to replicate without the resounding BOOM of a gun. You can really feel the concussion of many of these weapons. The graphics of them are at some points breathtaking. You trot several yards toward a distant wood-hewn fort, your many ranks of men beside you, having temporarily discarded your horses, and the fog is so thick, you can still barely make out the outline of the structure, though you know you must be close now. Suddenly, cries of germanic slang echo across the misty gully in front of a suddenly evident wooden wall, and more obviously, the gunshots follow, their concussions cutting through the haze like thunderclaps.Watching the blasts of powder-powered weaponry atop the walls of a wooden fort was all I needed to justify my purchase of this game.Then I got pushed off a siege ladder again.

												The only competition for Mount & Blade is another Mount & Blade.With Fire & Sword has been announced as "More M&B, now also with a story". It is basically a mod provided by the developers themselves, with a new (historical) map of Eastern Europe, new balancing and some tweaks. This is not M&B 2 or Warband 2, it is just a stand-alone Warband mod. The story takes place in a few "epic" quest chains, which offer a little more than the bare-bones open world medieval warfare simulator which the main game has always been. It is still 95% make-your-own-game open world, just spiced up a little.Be warned, difficulty is insanely high. You will try and fail many times before you even learn how to hold your own, let alone become powerful enough to win any significant battle unaided. I was originally surprised how bad the balancing and code quality were, but the post-launch patches have corrected many flaws and made it playable. Still frustratingly hard, but rewarding if you persist long enough.

Posted: February 26, 2012
												This game is a standalone xpac for one of my all time favorite franchises, Mount & Blade, but with historical factions and guns.  The fighting takes place in the 1650s during the Cossack uprising in Poland.  The game was a bit of a disappointment at release, due to some missing features (especially if you're coming from M&B: Warband) and a lot of bugs.  Its still buggy but its playable, especially with mods.  The SP is more story/quest driven than Warband, but make no mistake that its a sandbox game.  My favorite addition that it brings to the table is MP Captain mode, which allows you to control a squad of bots against other players or fight alongside them in cooperative mode.  This mode is actually really great; its fun to use your SP squad skills in MP, but there aren't a lot of people playing it anymore.  Overall Its a flawed game, but still a good one.

												For those of you who've played M&B Warband, what you'll find is a somewhat more limited but much more story-driven game, set during a very dynamic era in Eastern Europe's history. It's somewhat more limited as there are fewer 'roleplay' options and the economy seems less well developed, It's much more story-driven because instead of the over-arching "take over the world" objective, you have three different stories (Cossack, Muscovite, and Polish) you can engage in and leave 'on the back burner' at any time to return to the free-roaming sandbox world, which still exists largely unchanged from Warband. AI improvements: By default, a pike and shot formation will shelter the shot under the pikes. Ideal for defeating cavalry. Musketeers can kneel and fire. Reloading can be achieved on the move, though at a walk. In terms of the engine, WFAS and Warband are essentially identical, so expect smooth performance on any remotely reasonable gaming computer even at maximum settings.

Posted: August 28, 2015
												Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword takes place in 17th century Eastern Europe. There are five factions to choose from, the Polish Commonwealth, Muscovite Tsardom, Cossack Hetmanate, Kingdom of Sweden, and Crimean Khanate. Each faction has unique troops each with its pros and cons. There is a leveling system in this game so you can upgrade your character throughout the game. You can play in first person or third person. Throughout the game, you will recruit soldiers to join your troop. They can be upgraded once they have a certain amount of experience. You can also hire mercenaries too. In combat, you can command your troops to form a certain formation. The game is very similar to Mount & Blade: Warband. There is some addition in Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword, there are new weapons such as muskets, pistols, and grenades. There are some UI improvements as well.Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword is quite similar to its predecessor, Warband. The buildings and troop uniform look accurate. The towns and villages look nice. I really like the UI improvements, it's really neat. There are many mods for this game as well.However, there are some bugs and glitches in the campaign. The animation when someone died because of getting shot looks weird. There isn't much ragdoll from the grenades as well. Some aspects of the game, such as the loading screen, aren't optimized for widescreen resolution. There is no Steam Cloud support for this game too.To conclude, despite some of its flaws, Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword is still a very fun and addicting game. I really enjoy the hours I played it.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												I like the idea of a pike and shot campaign but this game was executed kind of poorly.Firstly, the battles aren't very fun after the novelty of gunpowder weapons wears off. The enemies often start way too close to you for you to give orders and try to win the battle tactically. This is especially bad for the era this game is set in. The effectiveness of muskets seems too random. Sometimes they will annihilate groups of soldiers, and sometimes they will do absolutely nothing. It's really frustrating when the enemy moves slowly enough to let me get 3 volleys off and my line of musketeers just hits no one. The worst thing is fighting the Crimean Khanate when they start really close and rush you with loads of cavalry before you can do anything at all.The problem with the sandbox map is that there are no large bandit groups. You want to practice and train your men on lowly bandit armies? You want someone to fight while your nation is not at war? Well forget that because bandits and rebels only come in groups of about 15. You can only have large battles against professional armies, which makes it  hard to train new recruits when they all die to large numbers of high tier soldiers. Not to mention attacking factions comes with consequences.There are some new features that I liked. For example, you can now go to a mercenary camp and recruit large numbers of soldiers like a standing army, and even buy them equipment. I had fun spending time and money equiping my army but then half of them died in their first battle. But other than a few things, the game is mostly unchanged from Warband. The main difference is the setting.You might like this game if you are going to try really hard and be patient, but for me it just isn't as fun as Warband. If you are new to Mount and Blade, I suggest getting Warband instead of this. M&B is just more suited to the medieval setting and Warband feels more complete.

Posted: December 28, 2015
												Gun powder weapons spice up the action but the muskets are WAY too over powered. This game takes place around the 16th century when guns weren't very reliable and insanely inaccurate, but in With Fire & Sword, you can snipe someone from about 200 feet away and get a freaking headshot on them about 80% of the time. This goes for singleplayer and multiplayer. Mounted units can still destroy any unit, which is fine. It's fun running over people while on horseback. You can recruit armies quickly with several types of mercenaries, it is easier to manage towns, earn money, and there are more options to manage your armies now in battle. It's pretty cool getting a few dozen musket units all lined up in a row and fire at the same time. Grenades do exactly what you would think. Posted: August 17, 2015
												Mount and Blade: With Fire and Sword is an interesting.. Sequel/Standalone whatever it is to Mount and Blade and Mount and Blade: Warband.While it proudly boasts the classic Mount and Blade style game play, allowing you free roam to do whatever you please in the world, be it conquer it, hunt bandits, or even just run caravans, there are a few things that make it exceptionally notable from the original game and it's sequel.The first, and most likely the most noticably, is the guns. Unlike the original and Warband, which were set in a medieval-esque setting, fit with Crossbows, Bows and Throwing weapons as the only ranged weapons, With Fire and sword is placed in the 17th century Polish-Lithuanian commonwealth, and, as such, the game features guns. Most people see this in the game, and are offput by it (Much like many were to Age of Empires III) figuring it to be game-ruining or cheap. Taleworlds are smarter than that though, and the method to which they added guns is quite interesting. Mount and blade is renowned for it's complex systems for calculating damage accuracy and speed, and the way they introduced guns fits perfectly into this. You see, the guns, like any weapon real life or (good) fantasy, have both pros and cons.Starting off with the pros, guns are incredibly powerful. A good shot to a person can very easily kill them instantly, and someone without a shield (something the game encourages by making them a bit pricey) can't block the shot. That on it's own would be ridiculously powerful, but it is weighed against the incredibly long reload times, limited shots and incredible inaccuracy. The weapons are treated by the game to be a sort of glass cannon: Incredibly powerful, but on it's own? Useless. Anyone with a mind wouldn't ride on their horse with a gun and without a sword. This makes for some incredibly interesting strategy and thought to be combined with the weapon, as is usual with the series.The second difference is in troop management. The player can only recruit so many troops from villages at the beginning, this means that they cannot stack up troops as they would in the other two games. Instead soldiers in the earlier game are comprised almost if not entirely of mercenaries. If this were how it were in Warband, the game would be absolutely unplayable. In With fire and sword, however, there are some major changes. Firstly, the mercenaries you build your armies out of can be hired as much as you like from a mercenary camp, and more interestingly, at a mercenary camp you can actually choose what gear your troops have (Much like with companions, although a bit less customizable)This allows you to tailor your army however you like it, albeit at a cost.  This feature is incredibly fun and interesting, although I believe it should have been optional to have the village recruitments for the most part turned off in the beginning, to allow more freedom.A downside to With Fire and Sword though is the lack of mods. This is of course not the fault of the developers, and much more the fanbase. The game didn't hit as much success as Warband did with the community, despite how well the game compares to it, and so the mod base, compared to Warband, is empty. This is a catastrophic shame, although even without mods the game on its own still has much merit.The game also isn't quite as memorable as the other games were. While the other games had their own original nations, With Fire and Sword draws more from actual history, and so contains real nations exclusively. This means that, while they are different culturally and strategically, they aren't as exuberant and different as the ones in the original games. The original two had everything from the desert dwelling Sarranids to the steppe venturing Khergits and snow wandering Vaegirs. While you could see the cultures they were drawn from, it was still interesting to see them all interacting with one another, and they were distinctly different. Not as many people know the difference between Russian troops and Polish ones as people do Viking and Arabian ones. These features aren't inherently bad, though. They can appeal greatly to a history buff with a passion for the 17th century. It is simply that these features aren't as appealing to a wide audience. Don't let me dissaude you though, With Fire and Sword is a wonderful game, even if you aren't as into history as some other people are. It holds up extremely well to it's counterparts and in some ways surpasses it. And, if you enjoyed either of the first two games, I highly reccomend you give this one a try, even if you don't like the game in the end, you won't regret any time spent in it.

												Mount and Blade: With Fire and Sword is an interesting.. Sequel/Standalone whatever it is to Mount and Blade and Mount and Blade: Warband.While it proudly boasts the classic Mount and Blade style game play, allowing you free roam to do whatever you please in the world, be it conquer it, hunt bandits, or even just run caravans, there are a few things that make it exceptionally notable from the original game and it's sequel.The first, and most likely the most noticably, is the guns. Unlike the original and Warband, which were set in a medieval-esque setting, fit with Crossbows, Bows and Throwing weapons as the only ranged weapons, With Fire and sword is placed in the 17th century Polish-Lithuanian commonwealth, and, as such, the game features guns. Most people see this in the game, and are offput by it (Much like many were to Age of Empires III) figuring it to be game-ruining or cheap. Taleworlds are smarter than that though, and the method to which they added guns is quite interesting. Mount and blade is renowned for it's complex systems for calculating damage accuracy and speed, and the way they introduced guns fits perfectly into this. You see, the guns, like any weapon real life or (good) fantasy, have both pros and cons.Starting off with the pros, guns are incredibly powerful. A good shot to a person can very easily kill them instantly, and someone without a shield (something the game encourages by making them a bit pricey) can't block the shot. That on it's own would be ridiculously powerful, but it is weighed against the incredibly long reload times, limited shots and incredible inaccuracy. The weapons are treated by the game to be a sort of glass cannon: Incredibly powerful, but on it's own? Useless. Anyone with a mind wouldn't ride on their horse with a gun and without a sword. This makes for some incredibly interesting strategy and thought to be combined with the weapon, as is usual with the series.The second difference is in troop management. The player can only recruit so many troops from villages at the beginning, this means that they cannot stack up troops as they would in the other two games. Instead soldiers in the earlier game are comprised almost if not entirely of mercenaries. If this were how it were in Warband, the game would be absolutely unplayable. In With fire and sword, however, there are some major changes. Firstly, the mercenaries you build your armies out of can be hired as much as you like from a mercenary camp, and more interestingly, at a mercenary camp you can actually choose what gear your troops have (Much like with companions, although a bit less customizable)This allows you to tailor your army however you like it, albeit at a cost.  This feature is incredibly fun and interesting, although I believe it should have been optional to have the village recruitments for the most part turned off in the beginning, to allow more freedom.A downside to With Fire and Sword though is the lack of mods. This is of course not the fault of the developers, and much more the fanbase. The game didn't hit as much success as Warband did with the community, despite how well the game compares to it, and so the mod base, compared to Warband, is empty. This is a catastrophic shame, although even without mods the game on its own still has much merit.The game also isn't quite as memorable as the other games were. While the other games had their own original nations, With Fire and Sword draws more from actual history, and so contains real nations exclusively. This means that, while they are different culturally and strategically, they aren't as exuberant and different as the ones in the original games. The original two had everything from the desert dwelling Sarranids to the steppe venturing Khergits and snow wandering Vaegirs. While you could see the cultures they were drawn from, it was still interesting to see them all interacting with one another, and they were distinctly different. Not as many people know the difference between Russian troops and Polish ones as people do Viking and Arabian ones. These features aren't inherently bad, though. They can appeal greatly to a history buff with a passion for the 17th century. It is simply that these features aren't as appealing to a wide audience. Don't let me dissaude you though, With Fire and Sword is a wonderful game, even if you aren't as into history as some other people are. It holds up extremely well to it's counterparts and in some ways surpasses it. And, if you enjoyed either of the first two games, I highly reccomend you give this one a try, even if you don't like the game in the end, you won't regret any time spent in it.

												Gun powder weapons spice up the action but the muskets are WAY too over powered. This game takes place around the 16th century when guns weren't very reliable and insanely inaccurate, but in With Fire & Sword, you can snipe someone from about 200 feet away and get a freaking headshot on them about 80% of the time. This goes for singleplayer and multiplayer. Mounted units can still destroy any unit, which is fine. It's fun running over people while on horseback. You can recruit armies quickly with several types of mercenaries, it is easier to manage towns, earn money, and there are more options to manage your armies now in battle. It's pretty cool getting a few dozen musket units all lined up in a row and fire at the same time. Grenades do exactly what you would think. Blasting a hole into the side wall of a castle and charging in is certainly alot faster and easier then using ladders during sieges. There's plenty of mods you can find to set your fix, just like the other Mount & Blade games. There are some other improvements here and there over Warband, but I think Warband is still the must have game out of this series and stand alone expansions. With Fire & Sword is still worth getting in my eyes; you'll just have to get used to the additions of guns and other new modes and features.

												I was told of this game by a friend while overseas. I mocked it mercilessly just because of the name.  Mount and Blade... Say it with authority and gusto, you'll get it.However, after spending a mere ten bucks on this game, I was surprised to see how crazy deep this game goes, yet only as deep as you want it to.  There is a whole political world that surrounds every action.  There is a tactical battle system that does less of that.If your okay with losing. A lot. Because F this game! then your in.  The learning curve is steep, and the time it takes to be able to actually feel like your doing ANYTHING is immense.  However, if your the hardest of the core, you will find one of the greatest games ten bucks can buy.  Wether you pledge fealty or try and strike it big on your own it takes planning, it takes thought, it takes forsight. Want to ambush your enemies in the field (which is dictated by where on the map you engage?)  Want to sack castles and/or forts to hold more land? By all means do so.  Want to distract with cavalry while your riflemen and infantry get into a perfect position to be lead to? Go for it. Dont wanna mess with all that tactical crap? Hop on your mount, weild that blade, and go to town.  I reiterate, I hope your ready to lose.  A lot.This game really is for the hardcore.  Nothing is fast and very little is easy.

Posted: February 12, 2016
												Prepare yourself to get shot randomly with fire and sword! (HAH!) Mount & Blade: With Fire & Sword, is a gem that manages to get interesting the more time you decide to invest in it.The main difference in MB: Warband and MB: With Fire & sword are the few but more interesting quests and the fact that you cannot survive without a gun. You can try but having a spare gun and some bullets makes your life much easier when fighting certain enemies. Now the one thing that makes me angry with a vicious fury, is the gun's mechanics in this game. Now I'm all for historical accuracy and muskets being inaccurate and unpredictable, but when a peasant from a mile away with a broken and cracked old pistol can headshot me... That's when I lose my sh!t. But it is a minor issue when you manage to play carefully and don't rush into battle without knowing you can win. But of course the unpredictable guns have many times been the reasons I hate this game at times. When one of your strongest soldiers get shot down in a quick charge against 3 bandits, that is not a nice time. The game has many ways for a lone soldier to survive in an eternally conflicted European time in history. Whether it be as merchant or mercenary, loyal subject or lone vigilante. MB: With Fire & Sword has it all. 7/10 - Quicksave (seriously) before ANY  battle.

												Thoguh many compare M&B WF&S to Warband,it doesn't make justice with this game.The key feature upon which the comparison is made is guns,and those drastically change the combat.In M&B and Warband it's more simple and easier, you can be a one man army,thinning the enemy's army while your troops engage the now more weaker bulk on the enemy's army.But in WF&S, combat is now more realistic and harder. You have to plan ahead and use the terrain and your troop versatility to your advantage.You need to think, is it better to have a highly armored units to serve as a target for the enemy's marksmen,to deplete their ammunition, making them easier to handle by your cavalry,or is it better to pound them with marksmen. While your horde of infantrymen closes on the enemyand overrunnig them by sheer numbers and using as an advantage the slow reload speed of the muskets.I truly enjoyed the more historical take of this expansion on eastern europe, (though I'm a bit bias because of my origins).The towns are truly beautiful and much better than the previous games.And it can be always improved by mods (I recommend WF&S Enhanced), which further enhance  the game.Worth the money
